title: Why has JK Rowling gone so far from her own canon? - Quora

response.answer_text: I personally do not think it really has much to do with JKR “not caring about her own stories” or “just milking her own franchise”. I actually do think that this is a story that she wants to tell. I mean, I remember reading the bits from Rita Skeeter’s book about Dumbledore in the Deathly Hallows and saying “Boy, I’d love to read the whole book”. I’m pretty sure a lot of people did, just like everyone kept asking JKR to write a Marauder’s book, or a book on the Hogwarts founder. All of those are still valid options for her as well. And to be honest, she isn’t the first writer to go back to her own universe to get more stories out of it, either. There is no point criticizing her for just that. The problem, and I think we should have seen this coming a long time ago, is that she isn’t the kind of writer who is suited for this “world expansion” kind of writing. At the heart of it all, Harry Potter novels were probably mystery novels. Yes, they follow the Hero’s Journey format. But I feel like that the mystery and suspense aspect of them were the best part. Although, she also builds characters, and relationships very well. Another thing she does well is give messages of equality and other social values, that she believes in. What was missing was the kind of coherence that would be present in a hard fantasy. The little slip-ups that do not really make sense. The lack of delving into “how magic works”. For example, everything that dealt with wandlore in the Deathly Hallows, they were more plot elements that were there to carry the story, to build towards that finish, rather than continuation of magical theory we have seen before. All these do lead towards that same conclusion, that she is better at writing mystery, with added social commentary and tales of friendship and love, than she is at writing a great High Fantasy which greatly maintains canon. This idea is bolstered further when she writes great mystery books that do not need to be veiled as magical fantasy (the Cormoran Strike novels). That is why, when she is writing Fantastic Beasts, or even before during the Cursed Child, she has not adhered to the history that she had created before. Neither does everything follow the rules of the established world. Thus the not unexpected departure from canon. PS: I also think that much of the flack that JKR is getting from the fandom for the Fantastic Beasts films should be pointed towards David Yates, who has been making the Potter films since Order of the Phoenix, and in my opinion never did a “great” job of bringing the books onto the large screen.

(long story short) JKR is in pro forma mode. Consider the statement “Potter fans waited three years between the releases of the fourth and fifth books.” I’d say that JKR’s enthusiasm for her series began to wane (or evanesce) at that point. There was plenty of “good stuff” in books five and six but book seven marched along “pro forma.” Books five through seven had increasing intervals of “Harry looked. He didn’t see anything. Harry searched. He didn’t find anything. Harry listened. He didn’t hear anything.” The most blantant of these intervals is when Harry doesn’t get any mail from his friends over the Summer and then they spend a lot of time cleaning Grimmaud Place. Another boring interval is the so-called Wizard camping trip. “OK. Let’s search all of the U.K. starting at the Outer Hebrides! (they find nothing)” So we can see that JKR’s wheels are slowing but she makes it (pro forma) to the end of her marathon. Then there is a nine or ten year ellipsis (commonly written …) before she restarts with Fantastic Beasts. The trouble here is that JKR decided to make these (five!) movies prequels to the main HP opus. If JKR had left Grindelwald out of the mix and left Dumbledore out of the mix, then you’d have a stand alone series of films. And now we discover that JKR seems to be writing the scripts in some sort of isolation booth. With a second or third pair of expert eyes invovled, surely the idea of a “secret brother” would have been scotched as cheap day-time TV drama. The term pro forma (Latin for "as a matter of form" or "for the sake of form") is most often used to describe a practice or document that is provided as a courtesy or satisfies minimum requirements, conforms to a norm or doctrine, tends to be performed perfunctorily or is considered a formality. scotched: decisively put an end to. "a spokesman has scotched the rumors" synonyms: put an end to, put a stop to, nip in the bud, put the lid on; ruin, wreck, destroy, smash, shatter, demolish, frustrate, thwart; informal put paid to, put the kibosh on, scupper, scuttle "the bad weather scotched our plans for a rematch" evanesce:to pass away or fade from sight like mist or smoke; disappear slowly
